page.title: 18FARM & LANDSCAPE CHANGES 2
page.content: {Dutch Elm Disease}spread rapidly across the country in the 1970s for the first time in several centuries. Elms were dominant in hedgerow and woodland and the death of almost all left dead trees to be felled,leaving gaping holes unlikely to be filled. Many of the hedgerows were removed al together,making cultivation by machine much faster.A few remain as shelter belts to protect crops against wind. The fewer,larger fields show on the 1:25000 map of 1982,though almost half the hedges on this map are missing today. {Hedges}in the Epping Upland area contain many species,a sign of their great age.Some are allowed to grow into trees,others are cut by flails, but few are properly layered to form boundaries secure against cattle:if needed,strands of barbed wire will do.
